title:
Kazhdan-Lusztig coefficients for an Affine Weyl group of type
  $\widetilde{A_2}$

title_detail.value:
Kazhdan-Lusztig coefficients for an Affine Weyl group of type
  $\widetilde{A_2}$

summary:
In this paper we compute the leading coefficients $\mu (u,w)$ of the
Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials $P_{u,w}$ for an affine Weyl group of type
$\widetilde{A_2}$. We give all the values $\mu (u,w)$.

summary_detail.value:

$\widetilde{A_2}$. We give all the values $\mu (u,w)$.

Abstract
In this paper we compute the leading coefficients μ(u, w) of the
Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials Pu,w for an affine Weyl group of type
f2 . We give all the values μ(u, w).

Introduction

Let W be a Coxeter group, on which there exists the Bruhat order. For
any u ≤ w in W , we have a Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomial Pu,w (q), where q
is an indeterminate (see [KL1]). The degree of Pu,w is less than or equal to
1
(l(w) − l(u) − 1) if u < w and Pw,w = 1, where l : W −→ N is the length
2
1
function on W. We denote by μ(u, w) the coefficient of the term q 2 (l(w)−l(u)−1)
in Pu,w , which will be called the Kazhdan-Lusztig coefficient of Pu,w .
The Kazhdan-Lusztig coefficient play a great important role in KazhdanLusztig theory, Lie theory and representation theory. By the recursive formula of Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials in [KL1], we see that some μ(u, w)
play crucial roles in understanding these polynomials.

Preliminaries

In this section we recall some basic facts about μ(u, w) which will be used
later.
Let G be a connected, simply connected reductive algebraic group over
the field C of complex numbers and T a maximal torus of G. Let NG (T ) be
the normalizer of T in G. Then W0 = NG (T )/T is a Weyl group, which acts
on the character group Λ = Hom(T, C∗ ) of T . Let Λr be the root lattic of
G, then the semi-direct product W = W0 ⋉ Λr is an affine Wely group and
f = W0 ⋉ Λ is called an extended affine Weyl group associated with G.

We recall some properties of the Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials.

Lemma 1.1 ([KL1]) We have the following results:
(1) For any u ≤ w in W , Pu,w is a polynomial in q with constant term 1.
(2) For any u < w with l(w) = l(u) + 1, we have Pu,w = 1. In particular, we
have μ(u, w) = 1 in this case.
(3) For any u < w with l(w) = l(u) + 2, we have Pu,w = 1.
(4) Pu,w = Psu,sw if u  sw for some s ∈ S and sw < w.
(5) Pu,w = Psu,w if u < w, sw < w for some s ∈ S.
(6) Pu,w = Pu−1 ,w−1 . In particular, μ(u, w) = μ(u−1, w −1 ).
(7) Let u, w ∈ W, s ∈ S be such that u < w, su > u, sw < w. Then u ≺ w
if and only if w = su. Moreover, this implies that μ(u, w) = 1.
(8) Let u, w ∈ W, s ∈ S be such that u < w, us > u, ws < w. Then u ≺ w
if and only if w = us. Moreover, this implies that μ(u, w) = 1.

Theorem 6.11 For any u < w, u ∈ c0 , w ∈ c1 such that l(w) − l(u) ≥ 5, we
have μ(u, w) = 0.
Proof. By the proof of the above Theorem, we see that L(w) ⊆ L(u) and
R(w) ⊆ R(u) if μ(u, w) 6= 0.
If | L(u) |= 2, without loss of generality, we assume that L(u) = {s, t}
and L(w) = {s}. When L(sw) = {t}, we have μ(u, w) = μ(ru, rw) by using
left star operation with respect to {s, r}. We see that rw ∈ c1 , ru ∈ c0 ,
l(rw) − l(ru) = l(w) − l(u), and L(ru) = L(rw) = {r}. When L(sw) = {r},
we have μ(u, w) = μ(ru, sw) by using left star operation with respect to
{s, r}. We see that sw ∈ c1 , ru ∈ c0 , l(sw) − l(ru) = l(w) − l(u) − 2, and
L(ru) = L(sw) = {r}. Similarly, we can discuss the same problem on the
right.
If l(w) − l(u) = 5, | L(u) |=| R(u) |= 2, and μ(u, w) = μ(u′, w ′) for
some u′ ∈ c0 , w ′ ∈ c1 satisfying | L(u′ ) |=| R(u′ ) |= 1 and l(w ′ ) − l(u′ ) =
l(w) − l(u) − 4 = 1. Then the u′ , w ′ must u′ ≮ w ′ , which implies that
μ(u, w) = μ(u′ , w ′) = 0.
For other cases, if | L(u) |= 2 or | R(u) |= 2, we can get μ(u, w) =
μ(u′, w ′ ) for some u′ ∈ c0 , w ′ ∈ c1 satisfying u′ < w ′, | L(u′ ) |=| R(u′ ) |= 1.
By Theorem 6.10, we can get μ(u, w) = μ(u′ , w ′) = 0.
We finish the proof.
